newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - May 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - May 23.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- China accused yesterday the Philippines of breaking international law by laying claim to Huangyan Island (Scarborough Shoal), adding that Manila's stand is "absolutely unacceptable to the Chinese government and people." (STANDARD/INQUIRER)

- The Philippines has rejected the proposal by the United States to use their former facilities in Clark and Subic for military exercises, a ranking diplomatic official said yesterday (STANDARD/TODAY)
- President Ramos called yesterday on the taipans of Hong Kong and China to consider the Philippines as their gateway to business and investments in southeast Asia. (ALL NEWSPAPERS)
- The Philippine Central Bank reduced yesterday its overnight borrowing by two percentage points to 18 percent as the financial markets returned to normal. (ALL NEWSPAPERS)

- The influential Bankers Association of the Philippines is strongly opposing the proposed amendments to the Bank Secrecy Law allowing certain government agencies to look into bank deposits. (CHRONICLE/STAR/BUSINESS DAILY)

- The scheduled bidding for the 7.5 percent shareholdings of state-owned National Development Corp in National Steel Corp faces another bleak prospect as few investors appeared interested in acquiring minority stake in the country's biggest steel firm. (BUSINESS DAILY/BUSINESSWORLD)
